title: Thousands fill Trafalgar Square to watch Oscar-nominated film by Iranian director boycotting ceremony over Donald Trump's immigration ban
text:

Thousands filled Trafalgar Square on Sunday to show support for an Iranian director who is boycotting the Oscars over Donald Trump's immigration ban. 
The massive turnout in central London doubled as the British premiere of Asghar Farhadi's Oscar-nominated film The Salesman, and a protest against the US president's controversial policy. 
Despite the cold weather thousands of people attended the free screening organised by Mayor Sadiq Khan and actors Keira Knightley, Dominic West and Lily Cole. 
It was held just hours before the Academy Awards in Los Angeles, which was expected to be the most politicised ceremony in years. Thousands showed their support for Iranian director Asghar Farhadi (Photo: REUTERS) The screening was held in Trafalgar Square in central London (Photo: REUTERS) Mr Farhadi appeared in a video message from Iran (Photo: REUTERS) 
After being nominated for a coveted award Mr Farhadi announced that he wouldn't attend the A-list bash in protest of Trump's policy. Read More This is how much an Oscar statuette is actually worth - and it's an absolute bargain 
Trump's executive order suspended refugee admissions for 120 days and banned people from seven Muslim-majority countries - Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen - from entering the US for 90 days. 
Mr Farhadi, who won an Oscar in 2012 for his film A Separation, is the bookies' favourite to win another statuette in the Best Foreign Language Film category. 
In a video message from Tehran, he thanked the "dear people of London" for their support and solidarity as they gathered in the cold. London Mayor Sadiq Khan addresses the crowd (Photo: REUTERS) A woman wears a hat designed in the colours of the Iranian flag (Photo: REUTERS) 
He told the crowd he was heartened by the reaction of filmmakers and artists to "the oppressive travel ban of immigrants". Read More Bill Paxton dead at 61: Aliens and Titanic actor passes away 'from surgery complications' 
He added: "I hope this movement will continue and spread for it has within itself the power to stand up to fascism, be victorious in the face of extremism and saying no to oppressive political powers everywhere." 
Mr Khan, who is Muslim, attended the screening and said to cheers from the crowd: "President Trump cannot silence me. 
"We stand in solidarity with Asghar Farhadi, one of the world's greatest directors." The screening was held just hours before the Academy Awards (Photo: REUTERS) 
Last year when Trump was elected the Mayor said the business mogul had an "ignorant" view of Islam. 
He has since called on the government to rescind its invitation for Trump to make a state visit. Read More Amber Rudd says concern over Tories scrapping child refugee scheme is 'fake news' 
Meanwhile Mr Farhadi is up against four films from Australia, Denmark, Germany and Sweden. 
The directors of those films joined him in issuing a statement criticising a "climate of fanaticism and nationalism" in the United States and elsewhere. Like us on Facebook
